Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Developing a Sensor-driven, Citizen Science Approach to Hazard Detection and Warning in Rural Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
For many communities, landslides represent catastrophic and difficult-to-predict hazard. Predicting landslides is a significant challenge, as soil conditions, localized rainfall, patterns of human development, and many other factors converge to trigger slides in ways still not well understood by the geoscience community. Meanwhile, landslide warning and response is fraught with challenges. Citizens can become desensitized by too many "false alarms", or warnings not relevant to their locale. Also, different social groups have different levels of trust in governmental authorities, science, and each other. Risk management thus requires significantly improved understanding of how to communicate warning to diverse communities and how to prepare them to respond adequately to this information. Using Sitka, Alaska as our example, this planning grant will expand a national network of physical and social scientific collaborators and link them to our existing science and community connections in Sitka and elsewhere in Alaska. The planning effort will deepen the team?s shared understanding of the natural science of hazard prediction and the social science and information technology of warning and response systems.

In order to improve the necessary shared understanding of landslide prediction, warning, and response, the physical and social science domains must be coupled and co-evolve as effective warning systems depend on accurate predictive capabilities. This project will connect geoscientists, social scientists, and local stakeholders together to determine the critical research questions around effective, needs-based hazard prediction, warning, and response. Through this work, we will accomplish the following goals: (1) prepare to deploy a landslide monitoring system, (2) plan to leverage data from sensors to improve predictive power for landslides, (3) create a framework to improve understanding of risk perception and communication across social networks in remote and diverse communities, and (4) lay the groundwork for a project that would leverage improved landslide prediction capacity and increased understanding of risk perception and communication to implement a warning system. The project will use the following approaches to accomplish this work: (1) meetings and engagements with local and national geoscientists, (2) methodological and technological survey of citizen science and distributed sensors, (3) application of risk perception, social network, and cultural measurement methods from health research, and (4) collaborative grant-writing. We expect the following impact for the planning grant and follow-on work: (1) improved techniques for hazard-related citizen science; (2) better technical and social approaches to hazard warning systems in diverse communities; (3) improved understanding of risk perception and community resilience to natural hazards in rural and remote communities, including those with Native American populations; (4) improved understanding of landslide hazard prediction through connecting science with regional and national datasets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT SUMMARY OVERVIEW

Landslides are destructive, hard to predict, and commonplace, especially in rural and remote communities with little existing infrastructure. Innovative approaches for improved prediction are becoming available and could help manage risk. Risk management thus also requires significantly improved understanding of how to communicate imperfect warnings to diverse communities and how to prepare them to respond adequately to this information. Using Sitka, Alaska as an example, the aims of the planning grant were to expand a national network of physical and social scientific collaborators and link them to existing science and community connections in Sitka, and to craft a follow-on proposal to the National Science Foundation to collaboratively build a smart and connected predictive warning system that increases community safety.

 The 2017 SCC planning grant enabled the study team to build strong ties with the Sitka community and a research plan reflective of Sitka?s needs. The planning grant furthered those connections and built new ones within the local and scientific communities via two trips to Sitka: one to attend the GeoTask Force meeting; the second to hold 25 meetings with a variety of groups and three open public meetings (meeting approximately 190 community members). As a result, the study team developed scientific and community networks across four universities, three federal agencies, an Alaska state agency, and nearly a dozen community partners. This full research team determined the critical research questions around effective, needs-based hazard prediction, warning, and response, and co-constructed and submitted a full grant proposal (NSF 18-520) with the Sitka community. The study team has been awarded the full grant, which will begin in October 2018.

 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Landslide risk management presents a highly complex problem demanding a focused, innovative, and multidisciplinary approach. Predicting landslides presents particular challenges, as soil conditions, localized rainfall, patterns of human development, and many other factors converge to trigger slides in ways still not well understood by the geoscience community. Landslide warning and response is fraught with human psychological, behavioral, and social challenges. Citizens can become desensitized by too many ?false alarms,? or warnings not relevant to their locale. In order to improve the necessary shared understanding of landslide prediction, warning, and response, the physical and social science domains must be coupled and co-evolve. The planning grant enabled the research team to bring the network of geoscientists, social scientists, and local stakeholders together to determine the critical research questions around effective, needs-based hazard prediction, warning, and response.

 The planning grant enabled social scientists to explore the possibilities for improving the understanding of risk perception and communication in social and cultural contexts, and consider how this can be translated into improved behavioral mitigation of natural hazards. The project supported information scientists to investigate how to incorporate multiple data streams from sources such as historical records and imagery, hydrologic sensors, and social networks, and how these diverse sources of data (of disparate time scales, dimensionalities, and levels of noise) can be integrated to improve decision-making and policy-making in highly uncertain environments. Geoscientists were able to look into new ways to use ground sensor data to improve landslide prediction. The team also discussed novel options for and better targeting of transmitting hazard warnings in rural and remote areas, including ways to extend warnings to those without wireless access, with local emergency managers.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

This project helped bridge diverse stakeholders in Sitka while simultaneously gaining an improved understanding of the dynamics of their interactions with each other and with the research community. This study provided direct means for the community to reflect on their own social connectedness and resilience through community focus groups and meetings with city leadership. The planning effort deepened the team?s shared understanding of the natural science of hazard prediction and the social science and information technology of warning and response systems. As a result, a $2.1 million grant has been awarded for a full proposal that will benefit society by demonstrating a system of easy-to-use, low-cost, smart and connected technologies that enable small, resource-constrained communities to significantly reduce landslide risk.
